briefTitle: Single Dose of Cervarix Vaccine in Girls or Three Doses of Gardasil Vaccine in Women for the Prevention of Human Papillomavirus Infection, the PRIMAVERA-ESCUDDO Trial
officialTitle: Non-Inferiority Trial Comparing Immunogenicity From 1-Dose of Bivalent HPV Vaccine in Girls to 3-Doses of Quadrivalent Vaccine in Women: The PRIMAVERA-ESCUDDO Trial ("Puente de Respuesta Inmunológica Para Mejorar el Acceso a Vacunas y Erradicar el Cancer")

interventions.name: Quadrivalent Human Papillomavirus (types 6, 11, 16, 18) Recombinant Vaccine
otherNames: Quadrivalent HPV [Type 6, 11, 16 and 18] L1 Virus-Like Particle vaccine
quadrivalent human papillomavirus (types 6, 11, 16, and 18) recombinant vaccine

interventions.name: Recombinant Human Papillomavirus Bivalent Vaccine
otherNames: Human Papillomavirus 16/18 L1 Virus-Like Particle/AS04 Vaccine
Human Papillomavirus Bivalent Types 16 and 18 Vaccine, Recombinant

summary: This phase IIIb trial compares a single dose of the Cervarix vaccine in girls to 3 doses of the Gardasil vaccine in young women for the prevention of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Cervarix is a vaccine used to prevent cervical cancer caused by HPV types 16 and 18. Gardasil is vaccine used to prevent cervical, vulvar, and vaginal cancer caused by HPV types 16 and 18 and genital warts caused by HPV types 6 and 11. Giving only one dose of the Cervarix vaccine in girls may work the same as 3 doses of the Gardasil vaccine in young women in preventing HPV infection and ultimately, cervical and other HPV-related cancers. Currently, many women around the world cannot get HPV vaccines because they are too expensive. If this trial can show one dose given to young girls is enough to prevent cancer, more girls might be able to get the vaccine.

primaryOutcome.measure: Number Seropositive for HPV16 at 36 Months

commonTop: Urinary tract infection, site not specified
